messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (missions near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-07-29T16:53:39Z
## Message ID: 20160729-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

S-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2016-07-28T22:24Z.

Estimated speed: ~350 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 45 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 10/7 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates (see [1] in Notes).

Activity ID: 2016-07-28T22:24:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary heliospheric analysis and modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CME may have an impact on NASA missions near Earth. The event associated with solar filament eruption is very complex and the transient may interact and merge with another approaching high speed solar wind stream region. It is estimated that the CME may reach Earth between 2016-08-01 and 2016-08-02 and cause moderate Kp 4-6 level of geomagnetic activity. Updates on this event will be provided when available.

Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME(s): 2016-07-28T22:24:00-CME-001):

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160729_085000_2.0_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160729_085000_2.0_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160729_085000_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160729_085000_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_B.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160729_085000_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160729_085000_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_B.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160729_085000_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160729_085000_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STA_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160729_085000_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STB_timeline.gif


## Notes: 

[1] http://iswawiki.gsfc.nasa.gov/wiki/index.php/Glossary/Heliospheric_Earth_Equatorial_coordinates

SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for July 20, 2016 - July 26, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-07-28T15:57:17Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-07-20T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-07-26T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160728-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at moderate levels during this reporting period with 7 M-class flares (see list below).  There were 4 C-type CMEs (see details below).   Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it was estimated that the CME starting at 2016-07-23T05:24Z may impact Dawn (glancing blow) around 2016-08-01T00:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) (see notification 20160723-AL-005).  

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2016-07-19T21:00Z to 2016-07-20T06:00Z and 2016-07-24T18:00Z-21:00Z.  This slight increase in geomagnetic activity at the beginning of the reporting period was associated with an interplanetary shock detected by ACE at L1 around 2016-07-19T23:00Z.  This signature could be the arrival of the two complex CMEs that started on 2016-07-17 (see notification 20160720-AL-003).  Simulations carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center indicated that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma crossed geosynchronous orbit starting at 2016-07-20T00:46Z due to this interplanetary shock (see notifications 20160720-AL-001 and 20160720-AL-002).  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.  


##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
2016-07-21  00:41:00  00:50:00  00:46:00   M1.2   N5W38 ( 12567 )  
2016-07-21  01:34:00  02:04:00  01:48:00   M1.0   N5W40 ( 12567 )  
2016-07-23  01:46:00  02:23:00  02:11:00   M5.0   N05W73 ( 12567 ) 
2016-07-23  05:00:00  05:24:00  05:16:00   M7.6   N05W73 ( 12567 ) 
2016-07-23  05:27:00  05:33:00  05:31:00   M5.5   N05W75 ( 12567 ) 
2016-07-24  06:09:00  06:32:00  06:20:00   M2.0   N06W89 ( 12567 ) 
2016-07-24  17:30:00  18:12:00  17:43:00   M1.9   N07W89 ( 12567 ) 

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2016-07-21T01:25Z     ~558            C              -140/23                27                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
2016-07-22T02:48Z     ~714            C                95/2                 35                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
2016-07-23T05:24Z     ~740            C                70/15                40                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
2016-07-25T01:25Z     ~500            C                91/-2                16                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-07-27T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-08-02T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  Former active regions 12565 and 12567 are now behind the west limb and can produce flares and coronal mass ejections on the far side.  Geomagnetic activity is currently elevated due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 on 2016-07-28.  Solar wind speeds are expected to remain elevated for the next few days.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Dawn)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-07-23T18:09:39Z
## Message ID: 20160723-AL-005
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2016-07-23T05:24Z.

Estimated speed: ~740 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 40 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 70/15 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates (see [1] in Notes).

Activity ID: 2016-07-23T05:24:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact Dawn (glancing blow).  The leading edge or flank of the CME will reach Dawn at 2016-08-01T00:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME(s): 2016-07-23T05:24:00-CME-001):

(a) 2 AU outer boundary
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160723_100700_2.0_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160723_100700_2.0_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160723_100700_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160723_100700_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_B.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160723_100700_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160723_100700_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_B.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160723_100700_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160723_100700_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STA_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160723_100700_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STB_timeline.gif

(b) 5.5 AU outer boundary
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160723_100700_5.5_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160723_100700_5.5_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160723_100700_5.5_ENLIL_CONE_Dawn_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160723_100700_5.5_ENLIL_CONE_Juno_timeline.gif


## Notes: 

This CME event (2016-07-23T05:24:00-CME-001) is associated with M7.6 flare with ID 2016-07-23T05:00:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2016-07-23T05:16Z (see notification(s) 20160723-AL-002) and M5.5 flare with ID 2016-07-23T05:27:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2016-07-23T05:31Z (see notification(s) 20160723-AL-003, 20160723-AL-004).

[1] http://iswawiki.gsfc.nasa.gov/wiki/index.php/Glossary/Heliospheric_Earth_Equatorial_coordinates

SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - M5.0, M7.6, M5.5 Flares
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-07-23T14:52:11Z
## Message ID: 20160723-AL-004
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

A sequence of significant flares were detected by GOES from N05W73 (Active Region 12565):

Flare start time: 2016-07-23T01:46Z
Flare peak time: 2016-07-23T02:11Z
Flare end time: 2016-07-23T02:23Z
Flare intensity: M5.0 class
Source region: N05W73 (Active Region 12565) (based on SDO imagery).
Activity ID: 2016-07-23T01:46:00-FLR-001

Flare start time: 2016-07-23T05:00Z 
Flare peak time: 2016-07-23T05:16Z
Flare end time: 2016-07-23T05:24Z 
Flare intensity: M7.6 class
Source region: N05W73 (Active Region 12565) (based on SDO imagery).
Activity ID: 2016-07-23T05:00:00-FLR-001

Flare start time: 2016-07-23T05:27Z 
Flare peak time: 2016-07-23T05:31Z
Flare end time: 2016-07-23T05:33Z 
Flare intensity: M5.5 class
Source region: N05W73 (Active Region 12565) (based on SDO imagery).
Activity ID: 2016-07-23T05:27:00-FLR-001

An enhancement of the > 10 MeV proton flux at GOES (0.77 pfu at 07:25Z) and > 15.8 MeV at SOHO (0.02 pfu/MeV at 08:30Z) was observed but the flux has decreased and continued to remain well below the thresholds of 10 pfu and 0.1 pfu/MeV respectively.

## Notes: 
The double-peaked M7.6 and M5.5 flares are associated with a CME starting on 2016-07-23T05:24Z. Updates on the CME will be provided when available (Activity ID 2016-07-23T05:24:00-CME-001).



NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Auto-generated Space Weather Notification - Flare intensity has crossed the threshold of M5.0
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-07-23T05:34:15Z
## Message ID: 20160723-AL-003
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:
 

Significant flare detected by GOES.  Flare intensity has crossed the threshold of M5.0.

Flare M5.0 crossing time: 2016-07-23T05:31Z. 

Increased energetic proton fluxes possible. Updates on this event will be provided when available.

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for July 13, 2016 - July 19, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-07-20T19:53:57Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-07-13T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-07-19T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160720-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low to moderate levels during this reporting period.  There were 3 C-type CMEs (see details below).   Based on heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it was estimated that the CMEs starting at 2016-07-17T11:24Z and Z2016-07-17T12:48Z may impact Mars between about 2016-07-22T03:38Z and 2016-07-22T12:16Z (average arrival 2016-07-22T07:05Z) for 18% of simulations, and also NASA missions near Earth between about 2016-07-20T13:46Z and 2016-07-21T10:39Z (average arrival 2016-07-20T23:32Z) for 91% of simulations (see notifications 20160718-AL-001 and 20160718-AL-002).  

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2016-07-19T21:00Z to 2016-07-20T06:00Z.  This slight increase in geomagnetic activity is associated with an interplanetary shock detected by ACE at L1 around 2016-07-19T23:00Z.  This signature could be the arrival of the two complex CMEs described above that started on 2016-07-17 (see notification 20160720-AL-003).  Simulations carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center indicated that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma crossed geosynchronous orbit starting at 2016-07-20T00:46Z due to this interplanetary shock (see notifications 20160720-AL-001 and 20160720-AL-002).  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES were elevated during the reporting period, but remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.  

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2016-07-17T12:48Z     ~584            C               -22/-2                29                          SOHO, STEREO A                    


Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2016-07-13T19:09Z     ~550            C               -50/-1                13                          STEREO A                          
2016-07-15T13:36Z     ~539            C                76/-26               25                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-07-20T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-07-26T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  There are a few active regions located on the solar disk that can produce solar flares or coronal mass ejections.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to remain elevated during the first few days of the next reporting period due to the ongoing transient activity described above.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significant interplanetary shock detected by ACE at L1 at 2016-07-19T23:05Z. 

This shock may be associated with an earlier than anticipated arrival of the CME 2016-07-17T11:24:00-CME-001 (see notification 20160718-AL-002).  Strong magnetospheric compression and geomagnetic storm expected. 

Activity ID: 2016-07-19T23:05:00-IPS-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Magnetopause Crossing
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-07-20T01:18:16Z
## Message ID: 20160720-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Strong compression of the magnetosphere detected. Simulations carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center indicate that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma is close to the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2016-07-20T00:46Z.

The activity is associated with Interplanetary Shock with ID 2016-07-19T23:05:00-IPS-001.

NASA spacecraft at the geosynchronous orbits may be exposed to solar wind plasma and magnetic field conditions.

Activity ID: 2016-07-20T00:46:00-MPC-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CMEs update (ensemble) (Mars, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-07-18T21:05:31Z
## Message ID: 20160718-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

BETA PRODUCT. ENSEMBLE PRODUCT IS STILL IN DEVELOPMENT MODE. PLEASE LET US KNOW IF YOU HAVE ANY SUGGESTIONS FOR MODIFICATIONS.  

Ensemble modeling update on CME(s) with ID(s) 2016-07-17T11:24:00-CME-001 and 2016-07-17T12:48:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20160718-AL-001). Based on heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CMEs may impact Mars. For 37 ensemble members (see notes section), simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach:

- Mars between about 2016-07-22T03:38Z and 2016-07-22T12:16Z (average arrival 2016-07-22T07:05Z) for 18% of simulations.

Additionally the CMEs is estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2016-07-20T13:46Z and 2016-07-21T10:39Z (average arrival 2016-07-20T23:32Z) for 91% of simulations.  The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 95% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 2-4 range (below minor to below minor).

Links to the ensemble details of the modeled event:
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2016-07-18_ncmes2_sims37_HILOX060/20160717_112400_ncmes2_sims37_HILOX060_anim_tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2016-07-18_ncmes2_sims37_HILOX060/20160717_112400_ncmes2_sims37_HILOX060_arrival_Earth.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2016-07-18_ncmes2_sims37_HILOX060/20160717_112400_ncmes2_sims37_HILOX060_Earth_stack.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2016-07-18_ncmes2_sims37_HILOX060/20160717_112400_ncmes2_sims37_HILOX060_probabilistic_Kp_forecast_wdist.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2016-07-18_ncmes2_sims37_HILOX060/20160717_112400_ncmes2_sims37_HILOX060_arrival_Mars.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2016-07-18_ncmes2_sims37_HILOX060/20160717_112400_ncmes2_sims37_HILOX060_Mars_stack.gif

## Notes:
Ensemble CME modeling at SWRC is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

For the full details of the modeled event, please go here:
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2016-07-18_ncmes2_sims37_HILOX060/Detailed_results_20160717_112400_ncmes2_sims37_HILOX060.txt

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CMEs (Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-07-18T18:21:48Z
## Message ID: 20160718-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Multiple CMEs have been detected as follows:
1: S-type CME detected by SOHO / STEREO A. 

Start time of the event: 2016-07-17T11:24Z.

Estimated speed: ~386 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 35 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -10/-3 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates (see [1] in Notes).

Activity ID: 2016-07-17T11:24:00-CME-001

2: C-type CME detected by SOHO / STEREO A. 

Start time of the event: 2016-07-17T12:48Z.

Estimated speed: ~584 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 29 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -22/-2 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2016-07-17T12:48:00-CME-001

 
Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CMEs may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CMEs will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2016-07-21T00:04Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 3-4 (below minor).
   

Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME(s): 2016-07-17T11:24:00-CME-001, 2016-07-17T12:48:00-CME-001):

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for July 06, 2016 - July 12, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-07-13T20:24:17Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-07-06T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-07-12T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160713-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very low levels during this reporting period.  There was 1 C-type CME (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2016-07-07T15:00Z-21:00Z, 2016-07-08T12:00Z-15:00Z and 2016-07-12T03:00Z-09:00Z.  The slight increase in geomagnetic activity at the beginning of the reporting period was associated with an arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 on 2016-07-07.  The second increase was associated with a second coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 on 2016-07-12.  The highest value of solar wind speed reached ~680 km/s on 2016-07-12.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week. 


##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-07-13T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-07-19T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  There are a few active regions located on the solar disk that can produce solar flares or coronal mass ejections.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to remain elevated during the first few days of the next reporting period due to the coronal hole high speed stream described above.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for June 29, 2016 - July 05, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-07-06T23:10:27Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-06-29T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-07-05T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160706-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were 4 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic period of 2016-07-02T21:00Z-24:00Z.  This minor increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 on 2016-07-02.  The highest values of solar wind speed reached 593 km/s on 2016-07-03.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  There are a few active regions located on the solar disk that can produce solar flares or coronal mass ejections.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to increase due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2016-07-07.
